data.title: Custom User Input in Exported .EXE game doesn't work on Steam or Steam Big Picture Mode
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Windows 10 64-bit

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
What happened is that I was test running an executable game on the Big Picture Mode in Steam and unfortunately, the joystick controls were not functioning in the game within the Steam Big Picture Mode, hopefully there may be a resolution to make the Godot Engine Executable to be more friendly for steam.

And just for heads up, I was using the Input maps for the Action pressed functions such as UI_Cancel and etc for both buttons and the joystick... However, I was using custom user interface inputs for a local multiplayer Idea.

Also, and additional note which strange enough is that the keyboard still works normally rather than the gamepad support, both the Steam Controller and the Xinput controllers does not work at all... Plus the controls, minus the steam controller works fine outside Big Picture Mode...

**Steps to reproduce:**
Make custom user input mapping that uses the joystick on the gamepad, Export your game to EXE or whatever works, open up Steam and bring in your game as a shortcut using "Add Non-Steam Game to library, Open up Big Picture Mode, go to where you've installed the game and see if you can get the joystick to work...

data.title: ImageTexture flag "Repeat" has no effect if "Mipmaps" is disabled.
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Windows 10 Pro x64

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Choosing only the flag `Repeat` does not make an ImageTexture repeat. Additionally, `Mipmaps` must be checked to make `Repeat` work.

Not sure if that combination makes sense, I don't remember needing to generate mipmaps for getting texture repeat to work in my old engine.

![untitled 1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9631152/15058171/13934b52-131b-11e6-88e5-94e1ccb3c32f.png)
![untitled 3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9631152/15058172/139404d4-131b-11e6-8840-a3642769c215.png)

data.title: Input.set_mouse_mode(Input.MOUSE_MODE_HIDDEN) hides cursor even on window chrome
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Windows 10 Pro x64

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Using `Input.set_mouse_mode(Input.MOUSE_MODE_HIDDEN)` hides the system cursor not only inside the client area where the game is displayed, it also hides it on top of the window chrome / border / frame / non-client area. This makes it hard to hit minimize / maximize / close buttons. Maybe this can be optimized.

data.title: Cannot document a module without forking Godot
data.body:
I'm writing a module for Godot, but I can't find a way to document it without modifying the global classes.xml or adding icons in tools/editor/icons.
This is impractical because it means I have to fork Godot.
It would be better to allow modules to be self-contained, have their own classes.xml file, icons etc. This way, modules could be versionned truly independently.

data.title: Fix build for Windows 64-bits with GCC
data.body: I believe now it's working for all compilers.

data.title: Fix JavaScript build
data.body: `opus_compare.c` isn't needed, and Emscripten doesn't like multiple `main` functions

data.title: Inconsistent window resize behavior
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Fedora linux (Gnome 3.20)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
It is supposed that setting window to non resizable should not let you resize the window, but when using this code weird things happen, sometimes the window resizes and sometimes it doesn't

**Steps to reproduce:**
    OS.set_window_size(Vector2(100, 100))
    OS.set_window_fullscreen(false)
    OS.set_window_resizable(false)
    OS.set_window_fullscreen(true)
    OS.set_window_fullscreen(false)
    OS.set_window_resizable(false)
    OS.set_window_size(Vector2(100, 100))

[window_problems.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/250808/window_problems.zip)

data.title: Fixed autocomplete truncate, issue 4554
data.body:
Fixed autocomplete truncating / overwriting characters.

closes #4554

data.title: Resource view doesn't respond
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Arch Linux  64bit

The editor is compiled from master (latest commit was 9487a9b3c25f)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

The resource view (or called resource window) doesn't respond when click or double click any resource file.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Open a project with godot editor
2. Click any resource file or folder.
3. Click any resource file or folder again it doesn't respond any more.

data.title: Editor crashes in some cases when trying to autocomplete
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Ubuntu 16.04
Godot compiled from master (latest commit was 9487a9b3c25f23942561eba20edce24f4be6f148)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
the editor crashes

**Steps to reproduce:**
make a new script:
`var x`
`_ready()`:
`x=x. #crashes when typing the dot`

This is pretty useless example but same thing can happen in scripts that extend another script,
when the editor can't tell the type of a variable.

data.title: Auto completion truncates word to the right
data.body:
Typing code to the left of another variable overwrites it as soon as characters are matched. This can be slightly annoying and produce unwanted syntax errors.

Here's an example: The o from "global" overwrites the o from "output", resulting in "utput".
![gif2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9631152/15043415/1847fd80-12cd-11e6-970d-fd673b3c6ba6.gif)

data.title: fix percent decode utf8 error
data.body:
closes #4066

Tested with

```
func _ready():
    var s = "aÖÜÄx"
    print(s)
    var de = s.percent_decode() #error
    print(s)
    print(de)
    var dict = {}
    dict[de]="test"
    print(dict)

    print("----")
    var se = s.percent_encode()
    print(se)
    de = se.percent_decode()
    print(s)
    print(de)

    print("----")
    var s = "ax"
    print(s)
    de = s.percent_decode()
    print(de)
    de = de.percent_encode()
    print(de)
    de = de.percent_decode()
    print(s)
    print(de)
```

data.title: Fix wrong return and argument types in documentation
data.body:
Fixed some incorrect return and argument types (including default values).

While doing it, noticed `Vector2Array` was not being checked by the documentation and it was also missing from `Variant::operator String()`.

data.title: Nested functions
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
It would be great if we could have nested functions inside GDscript. Nested functions would allow to divide script into significantly higher amount of 'logic blocks' without loosing readability. It's one of the features most modern languages don't support, which I personally miss the most. 
Interestingly nested functions are present in Python and since GdScript is Python-similar I think it would be a nice addition.

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: GDscript overwriting does not works
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Godot 2.0.2 win64 official release

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When you click on the "Edit/create the Node Script" button into Scene panel, there is a "Create Script for Node" dialog box which appears.
When you click the ".." path button, an other dialog box appears.
When you select a script that already exists, a confirmation box ask you if you want to overwrite it.
If you reply "OK", the previous "Create Script for Node" dialog box refuses to overwrite it.

**Steps to reproduce:**
![bug_0_0](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9801802/15012984/07ab588a-11fd-11e6-821d-a04e5afcb1d8.png)
![bug_0_1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9801802/15012988/0aee4ebc-11fd-11e6-95e0-8967621be6a6.png)
![bug_0_2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9801802/15012989/0d95bde4-11fd-11e6-8aa4-6ad0252d2e65.png)
![bug_0_3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9801802/15012992/101b89ae-11fd-11e6-8dcd-e3f0231ec2f6.png)
![bug_0_4](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9801802/15012995/12bc4edc-11fd-11e6-9721-af24774b2023.png)

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Fix ds3 gamepad mapping

data.title: Fix windows 64-bits build.
data.body:
The change in `tools/doc/doc_data.cpp` is needed because the MSVC compiler does not support variable length arrays.

Tested with MSVC x86 and x64 compilers with `scons p=windows target=release_debug`.

@Marqin may want to have a look at this.

Fix #4113

data.title: Wrong input mapping for Dual Shock 3 over bluetooth
data.body:
Operating system or device: Gnome Ubuntu Linux 16.04

Issue description (what happened, and what was expected): By trying to configure DS3 in my game I realised that the suggestion given by the editor for the buttons is completely wrong (ex: button 0 --> PS = X, Nintenda = A, etc...). Turns out, for instance, that select button is the godot X
Emoticon. How can I get the button mapping so to not going for a "trial and error" approach?

Steps to reproduce: Project settings --> input map: Map the buttons and test it.
